Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "[docs] Add template file for draft release notes" (#3331) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
The idea for this new `Documentation/release-notes/master.md` file is
that each time a new user-facing bug fix or feature is merged to
`master`, the author(s) of the change will add a corresponding draft
release note to this file.  The note can be added as part of the source
code pull request itself, or it can be added in a separate follow-up
pull request shortly afterward.

If the note for a new feature uses images, the images can be added to
`Documentation/release-notes/images/`.

Authors of new fixes and improvements don't need to do anything special
if their changes get cherry-picked from `master` to a release branch.
The team members who handle final release notes preparation and
publication will copy or move notes as needed from `master.md` to
earlier releases for changes that get cherry-picked.

The `master.md` template follows the same section order as the [final
published release notes][0], but it omits a few details like release
dates that aren't needed in the draft format.

The final notes also follow the text formatting rules described in the
[xamarin-docs contribution guidelines][1].  The draft notes don't need
to follow those guidelines too strictly.  For example, it's fine to use
backticks around paths in these draft notes rather than italics.  That
makes it easier to avoid unintentional formatting issues when paths
include characters like `_` or `*`.

Similarly, there's no need to worry about list indentation or line
wrapping in these draft notes.  Authors can optionally wrap lines to 80
characters and indent list items to match the example items, but it's
not required.

As part of branching for a new release, the current `master.md` file
will be renamed to match the new release branch name, and a new empty
template `master.md` file will be added by copying the original template
from this commit and updating the version numbers.

[0]: https://docs.microsoft.com/xamarin/android/release-notes/
[1]: https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/xamarin-docs/blob/live/contributing-guidelines/template.md

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Increase AndroidClientHandler timeouts" (#3328) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
`AndroidClientHandler` has no way of accessing the `HttpClient.Timeout` property
in order to set the timeout value of *two* native http client
properties (connect and read timeouts) and so it uses two custom properties to
provide these values. So far, the values were set to 100s for the read timeout
and 120s for the connect timeout, which seemed to be a reasonable value for
their purposes. However, if a developer sets `HttpClient.Timeout` to a
value *larger* than our defaults, `AndroidClientHandler` values "win" and the
connection/read time out earlier. The workaround is to set "our" timeouts along
with the `HttpClient` one, but if the developer cannot do it, for any kind of
reasons (i.e. to avoid platform-specific code) then they are faced with an
annoying situation.

The real fix would be to improve `HttpClient` API so that its associated client
handler can access `HttpClient` properties, but since it's not a quick fix we
can implement now, this commit bumps the default timeout values to
the (unreasonable) value of 24h to make sure we use values higher than the most
likely figures assigned to `HttpClient.Timeout` and to match Xamarin.iOS
NSUrlSessionHandler defaults.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Import Configuration.props in Mono.Android-Test.Library" (#3320) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Events.RelatedBody:
Context: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_build/results?buildId=2819142
Context: https://github.com/xamarin/xamarin-android/commit/e9561076a8e8761002931b886991eb1616561864

When this additional test library was added in e956107 it did not import
our Configuration.props file which contains default paths to the Android
tooling that we provision. This recently caused a breakage when bumping
the TargetFrameworkVersion of this project to v10.0 and building against
a system install of XA, as the Android SDK path which was automatically
resolved did not contain an android-29/android.jar. Importing the
Configuration.props file should fix this build failure.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Android.Views.Accessibility.Action is a flagged enum" (#3102) at xamarin/xamarin-android
Opened issue "[Enhancement] Modal dialog with swipe down to dismiss" (#6807) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
## Summary
Modal dialogs / pages with swipe down to dismiss is becoming more and more popular and Xamarin Forms should support it.
This is already possible in Xamarin Forms by creating a custom control and doing custom animations but I think it should be a part of the framework as it's own control.

## Intended Use Case
A control that look and feel just like the one in AppStore for iOS

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "GetTemplateChild  for DataTemplate" (#6806) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
Hi,

Please provide an easier and clean way to access child items inside the DataTemplate using the **GetTemplateChild** ..

For example:

```
<DataTemplate x:Key="HomePageSortTemplate">
    <ContentView BackgroundColor="White" x:Name="HomePageContentView">
        <StackLayout>
            <Grid HorizontalOptions="FillAndExpand" VerticalOptions="FillAndExpand" Padding="15">
                <Grid.RowDefinitions>
                    <RowDefinition Height="Auto" />
                </Grid.RowDefinitions>

		<Label x:Name="myLabel" Grid.Row="0" Text="This is my Label" />
            </Grid>
        </StackLayout>
    </ContentView>
</DataTemplate>

```
and then if I want to read the or set the value of the Label:

```
Label _myLabel;
_myLabel = GetTemplateChild("myLabel");

// Set the Value;
_myLabel.Text = "This is the New Text";

// Read the Value;
DisplayAlert("Value", _myLabel.Text, "OK");

```

Thanks,
[Jassim](https://www.softnames.com)

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Clear global routes on unit tests and process global routes in the right place" (#6781) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
### Description of Change ###
- Since we throw an exception now if you register the same route twice we need to clear the global routes in the teardown of the unit tests
- Global Routes were moved to only be processed if the ShellContent was specified as part of the uri but they should just be processed regardless

### Testing Procedure ###
- UI tests cover

### PR Checklist ###

- [x] Has automated tests <!-- (if tests are omitted or manual, state reason in description) -->
- [x] Rebased on top of the target branch at time of PR
- [x] Changes adhere to coding standard

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug] GTK Navigation is broken" (#6805) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
Steps to reproduce.
On master page and detail page add a button to the navigation bar
navigate from master page to detail page. Navigation bar is displayed (as expected)
Click on the back button and navigate again to the detail page
AR: Navigation bar is not displayed
ER: Navigation bar is displayed

Screen shots #4409

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug] Shell SearchHandler - Search text getting lost on execute search" (#6804) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description

When using the Xamarin.Forms Shell template and upgrade to Xamarin.Forms 4.1 (I did not test with 4.0 yet), the SearchHandler is removing the search term on enter/search execution. 

![SearchHandlerBug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25636075/60759349-14381f80-a024-11e9-8525-44f9fe86ab5f.gif)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a fresh Xamarin.Forms Shell project
2. Add a search handler

### Expected Behavior

It should keep the searched term.

### Actual Behavior

It losts the content.

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 4.1.0
- Last known good version: -
- IDE: VS2019 and VS for Mac
- Platform Target Frameworks: 
  - iOS:  Tested with iOS 12 Simulator

### Screenshots

Already added above in the description.

### Reproduction Link

Reproduction can be done with the VS template within a minute.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug] ListView does ignore left/right SafeArea even if it is the root control (Shell problem?)" (#6803) at xamarin/Xamarin.Forms
Events.RelatedBody:
<!-- Bug report best practices: https://github.com/xamarin/Xamarin.Forms/wiki/Submitting-Issues -->

### Description

ListView, even when set to the root element of a page, ignores the SafeArea for left and right.

Also the ListView is now cut off at the bottom??

![Bildschirmfoto 2019-07-06 um 19 22 12](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25636075/60759308-62005800-a023-11e9-925c-954ce407cfc9.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a fresh Xamarin.Forms Shell project
2. Move the ListView from the StackLayout to the ContentPage.Content directly (only in this case it has worked before)

### Expected Behavior

The ListView, at least when it is the root control of a page, should respect the SafeArea margins like it has done in 3.6. 

### Actual Behavior

Looks broken.

### Basic Information

- Version with issue: 4.1.0
- Last known good version: 3.6.0
- IDE: VS2019 and VS for Mac
- Platform Target Frameworks: 
  - iOS:  Tested with iOS 12 Simulator

### Screenshots

Already added above in the description.

### Reproduction Link

Reproduction can be done with the VS template within a minute.
